elements.content: A novel Zr­(IV) dicarboxylate metal organic framework (MOF) built up from an s-tetrazine derived ligand was prepared. This solid, which exhibits a diamond type network, combines a good stability in water, a structural flexibility, and fluorescence properties thanks to the organic ligand. It is noteworthy that this fluorescence is quenched when exposed to electron-rich molecules in solution, such as amines or phenol, this phenomenon being associated with the adsorption of the quencher, as unambiguously proven by X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis. Finally, the quenching efficiency is shown to be governed not only by electronic and steric factors but also by the relative polarity of the solvent, the MOF, and the quencher. This work thus suggests that it is possible to develop new MOF-based sensors presenting in a given medium (such as water) highly selective responses.
elements.clean_text: A novel Zr(IV) dicarboxylate metal organic framework (MOF) built up from an s-tetrazine derived ligand was prepared. This solid, which exhibits a diamond type network, combines a good stability in water, a structural flexibility, and fluorescence properties thanks to the organic ligand. It is noteworthy that this fluorescence is quenched when exposed to electron-rich molecules in solution, such as amines or phenol, this phenomenon being associated with the adsorption of the quencher, as unambiguously proven by X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis. Finally, the quenching efficiency is shown to be governed not only by electronic and steric factors but also by the relative polarity of the solvent, the MOF, and the quencher. This work thus suggests that it is possible to develop new MOF-based sensors presenting in a given medium (such as water) highly selective responses.

elements.content:
A robust, flexible and fluorescent Zr­(IV) s-tetrazine MOF is able to detect electron-rich molecules in solution.

Introduction

While porous coordination polymers (PCPs) or metal organic frameworks (MOFs) have been primarily considered as promising candidates mainly for separation and storage purposes, their use for the detection of chemical species by adsorption is also appealing. Thanks to their porosity and high chemical and structural diversity, MOFs might indeed combine a high level of detection (thanks to the adsorption) and a tunable selectivity, based on the combination of steric (size exclusion) and electronic (preferential/specific host–guest interactions such as hydrogen or halogen bonds or donor–acceptor interactions) factors. Fluorescence-based optical detection by MOFs is probably the most studied case. While lanthanide-based MOFs have been extensively used, luminescence arising from the organic ligand (either as an intrinsic property or indirectly through ligand to metal or metal to ligand charge transfer) is of high interest, notably because of the likely higher sensitivity of the luminophore to the guest (especially when organic). MOFs presenting a fluorescence sensitive to inorganic anions and cations, protons, gases, and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) or nitroaromatic explosives (electron-poor molecules) have thus been studied recently. Electron-rich species, such as aromatic amines or phenol derivatives, have been addressed less frequently although their potential hazard, e.g., in water, is established.
elements.clean_text:
A robust, flexible and fluorescent Zr(IV) s-tetrazine MOF is able to detect electron-rich molecules in solution.

Introduction

While porous coordination polymers (PCPs) or metal organic frameworks (MOFs) have been primarily considered as promising candidates mainly for separation and storage purposes, their use for the detection of chemical species by adsorption is also appealing. Thanks to their porosity and high chemical and structural diversity, MOFs might indeed combine a high level of detection (thanks to the adsorption) and a tunable selectivity, based on the combination of steric (size exclusion) and electronic (preferential/specific host-guest interactions such as hydrogen or halogen bonds or donor-acceptor interactions) factors. Fluorescence-based optical detection by MOFs is probably the most studied case. While lanthanide-based MOFs have been extensively used, luminescence arising from the organic ligand (either as an intrinsic property or indirectly through ligand to metal or metal to ligand charge transfer) is of high interest, notably because of the likely higher sensitivity of the luminophore to the guest (especially when organic). MOFs presenting a fluorescence sensitive to inorganic anions and cations, protons, gases, and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) or nitroaromatic explosives (electron-poor molecules) have thus been studied recently. Electron-rich species, such as aromatic amines or phenol derivatives, have been addressed less frequently although their potential hazard, e.g., in water, is established.

elements.content: Our aim here was to build up a robust MOF suitable for the detection of electron-rich molecules, especially in aqueous medium. The Zr­(IV) cation appears suitable for such a purpose, as it usually leads to chemically stable MOFs (especially in humid environment), and does not involve any absorption in the visible range. Indeed, Zr­(IV) carboxylate-based MOFs efficient for optical detection (mostly by fluorescence), especially of the pH, have been reported. Regarding the fluorophore, we focused our attention on a small electron-poor luminophore, the s-tetrazine, whose fluorescence is known to be quenched by electron-rich molecules, and which has shown useful properties and applications. Few MOFs built up from s-tetrazine derived ligands have been reported to date, mostly based on M­(II) cations. One of these solids was found to exhibit solvatochromism upon adsorption of solvents. Recently, Kaskel et al. reported the doping of the Zr­(IV) terephthalate UiO-66 by the hydrotetrazinedicarboxylate (i.e., reduced form of s-tetrazine) for the detection of oxidative gases (nitrous gas and bromine) by redox reactions. Nevertheless, to the best of our knowledge, their fluorescence properties have not been exploited for detection purposes so far.
elements.clean_text: Our aim here was to build up a robust MOF suitable for the detection of electron-rich molecules, especially in aqueous medium. The Zr(IV) cation appears suitable for such a purpose, as it usually leads to chemically stable MOFs (especially in humid environment), and does not involve any absorption in the visible range. Indeed, Zr(IV) carboxylate-based MOFs efficient for optical detection (mostly by fluorescence), especially of the pH, have been reported. Regarding the fluorophore, we focused our attention on a small electron-poor luminophore, the s-tetrazine, whose fluorescence is known to be quenched by electron-rich molecules, and which has shown useful properties and applications. Few MOFs built up from s-tetrazine derived ligands have been reported to date, mostly based on M(II) cations. One of these solids was found to exhibit solvatochromism upon adsorption of solvents. Recently, Kaskel et al. reported the doping of the Zr(IV) terephthalate UiO-66 by the hydrotetrazinedicarboxylate (i.e., reduced form of s-tetrazine) for the detection of oxidative gases (nitrous gas and bromine) by redox reactions. Nevertheless, to the best of our knowledge, their fluorescence properties have not been exploited for detection purposes so far.

elements.content: We report here the synthesis and characterization of a Zr­(IV) MOF built up from a newly designed s-tetrazine ligand, later denoted MIL-161 (MIL stands for Material Institute Lavoisier). This solid is shown to be stable in aqueous medium, structurally flexible (i.e., the pore size and shape adapt to its content while the solid remains crystalline), and fluorescent, such fluorescence being quenched by electron-rich species. Specifically, the combination of fluorescence and structural flexibility is used to shed some light on the quenching mechanism. Finally, the impact of the hydrophobic/hydrophilic balance within the MOF, the electron-rich quencher, and the solvent on the quenching efficiency is addressed.
elements.clean_text: We report here the synthesis and characterization of a Zr(IV) MOF built up from a newly designed s-tetrazine ligand, later denoted MIL-161 (MIL stands for Material Institute Lavoisier). This solid is shown to be stable in aqueous medium, structurally flexible (i.e., the pore size and shape adapt to its content while the solid remains crystalline), and fluorescent, such fluorescence being quenched by electron-rich species. Specifically, the combination of fluorescence and structural flexibility is used to shed some light on the quenching mechanism. Finally, the impact of the hydrophobic/hydrophilic balance within the MOF, the electron-rich quencher, and the solvent on the quenching efficiency is addressed.

elements.content: As the simplest dicarboxylic s-tetrazine is rather unstable and poorly fluorescent, a sulfur derivative of tetrazine bearing two carboxylic groups (later labeled H2STz, see ) was prepared at the gram scale in one step starting from the 3,6-bis­(3,5-dimethylpyrazol-1-yl)-s-tetrazine (see Supporting Information for details).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Structure Determination

As the simplest dicarboxylic s-tetrazine is rather unstable and poorly fluorescent, a sulfur derivative of tetrazine bearing two carboxylic groups (later labeled H2STz, see ) was prepared at the gram scale in one step starting from the 3,6-bis(3,5-dimethylpyrazol-1-yl)-s-tetrazine (see Supporting Information for details).

elements.clean_text: 1   s-Tetrazine Dicarboxylic Acid (H2STz) Used in the Present Study

elements.content: As expected for such a s-tetrazine derivative, the UV–visible absorption spectrum presents two absorption bands, centered at 409 and 525 nm (ε = 818 and 481 L mol–1 cm–1 respectively) and associated with π–π* and n−π* electronic transitions, respectively. After excitation at either 409 or 525 nm, an emission peak centered at 580 nm is observed with a modest quantum yield (0.4(2) %), again in agreement with previous studies of thiol functionalized s-tetrazines (Figure S16).
elements.clean_text: As expected for such a s-tetrazine derivative, the UV-visible absorption spectrum presents two absorption bands, centered at 409 and 525 nm (ε = 818 and 481 L mol-1 cm-1 respectively) and associated with π-π* and n-π* electronic transitions, respectively. After excitation at either 409 or 525 nm, an emission peak centered at 580 nm is observed with a modest quantum yield (0.4(2) %), again in agreement with previous studies of thiol functionalized s-tetrazines (Figure S16).

elements.content: The reactivity of H2STz with Zr salts in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) was first investigated using the high-throughput methodology developed by Stock et al., which allowed exploration of a broad range of reaction conditions with a minor amount of reactants. Few key parameters were identified, namely, the nature of the Zr­(IV) precursor, the temperature, and the hydrochloric solution (HCl) content. Among the Zr­(IV) precursors tested (isopropoxide, acetylacetonate, chloride), only the latter led to crystalline product. At a moderate temperature (60–80 °C) and in the presence of HCl (HCl/Zr = 4), the reaction of a stoichiometric amount of ZrCl4 with H2STz afforded a red polycrystalline powder. Using a higher temperature (100 °C) led to an improvement of the crystallinity together with the appearance of a crystalline impurity. This later was isolated as single crystals and identified as resulting from an intramolecular cyclization reaction of the ligand (see Supporting Information for details). Thus, all characterizations were then carried out on the pure material obtained at low temperature, except the structure determination from X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD), which was performed on a batch synthesized at 100 °C (see Supporting Information for details). Because of the flexible character of MIL-161 leading to a broadening of the Bragg peaks upon drying (see below and Figure S11), high resolution synchrotron data suitable for structure determination were collected while the solid was suspended in solvents. Structures were solved both in DMF and in water (see Figures S4 and S5 for the final Rietveld plots) in order to shed some light on the flexible behavior (see below). MIL-161 crystallizes in a tetragonal setting, space group I4̅2d (No. 122), with cell parameters depending on the nature of the absorbed solvents (see ).
elements.clean_text: The reactivity of H2STz with Zr salts in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) was first investigated using the high-throughput methodology developed by Stock et al., which allowed exploration of a broad range of reaction conditions with a minor amount of reactants. Few key parameters were identified, namely, the nature of the Zr(IV) precursor, the temperature, and the hydrochloric solution (HCl) content. Among the Zr(IV) precursors tested (isopropoxide, acetylacetonate, chloride), only the latter led to crystalline product. At a moderate temperature (60-80 °C) and in the presence of HCl (HCl/Zr = 4), the reaction of a stoichiometric amount of ZrCl4 with H2STz afforded a red polycrystalline powder. Using a higher temperature (100 °C) led to an improvement of the crystallinity together with the appearance of a crystalline impurity. This later was isolated as single crystals and identified as resulting from an intramolecular cyclization reaction of the ligand (see Supporting Information for details). Thus, all characterizations were then carried out on the pure material obtained at low temperature, except the structure determination from X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD), which was performed on a batch synthesized at 100 °C (see Supporting Information for details). Because of the flexible character of MIL-161 leading to a broadening of the Bragg peaks upon drying (see below and Figure S11), high resolution synchrotron data suitable for structure determination were collected while the solid was suspended in solvents. Structures were solved both in DMF and in water (see Figures S4 and S5 for the final Rietveld plots) in order to shed some light on the flexible behavior (see below). MIL-161 crystallizes in a tetragonal setting, space group I4̅2d (No. 122), with cell parameters depending on the nature of the absorbed solvents (see ).

The asymmetric unit contains two Zr­(IV) ions, three μ3-oxo bridges, one STz ligand, and solvent molecules (DMF and water). This leads to the formula Zr6O8(STz)4(solvent) n , which was confirmed by infrared spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis, solid state NMR, and chemical analyses (see Supporting Information for details).
elements.clean_text: The asymmetric unit contains two Zr(IV) ions, three μ3-oxo bridges, one STz ligand, and solvent molecules (DMF and water). This leads to the formula Zr6O8(STz)4(solvent) n , which was confirmed by infrared spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis, solid state NMR, and chemical analyses (see Supporting Information for details).

elements.content: Both Zr­(IV) ions are 8-fold coordinated and assemble into the well-established Zr6O8 oxocluster (a). Each inorganic unit is surrounded by eight carboxylate groups arising from the ligands. While MOFs built up from 12-connected Zr6 oxoclusters are the most common, many recent studies have described new solids built up from carboxylate deficient Zr6 nodes (either 10, 8, or 6 connected). In the case of the 8-fold connection, the carboxylates are usually organized to define a cubic geometry (point group symmetry D 4h ). In the present solid, they define a rare triangular gyro-biprism or gyrobifastigium (obtained by fusing together two triangular prisms through a square face after a 90° rotation) with an ideal D 2d symmetry (see Figure S7). The ligands assemble into dimers with their rings roughly parallel to each other, with one carboxylate group in the plane of the aromatic ring and one outside (see b and S8). These dimers connect two oxoclusters together, leading on the whole to a distorted diamond (dia) type network (c). Regarding the protonation state of the inorganic μ3 ligands (O2–/OH–), the structure solution indicates the presence of terminal DMF molecules and hence likely charge balancing oxo bridges giving rise to the formula Zr6O8(STz)4(DMF)8. Nevertheless, the final protonation state might depend on the activation procedure, and its unambiguous determination in carboxylate deficient Zr6 units is still an issue and a matter of debate. Indeed, as proposed by Zhou et al. for PCN-222, a washing step with an aqueous HCl solution prior to activation seems to qualitatively improve the crystallinity of MIL-161, together with a positive impact on the reversibility of the flexible behavior (see Figure S10). While the mechanism is not clear, it might be associated with acid–base reactions involving bridging and/or terminal ligands.
elements.clean_text: Both Zr(IV) ions are 8-fold coordinated and assemble into the well-established Zr6O8 oxocluster (a). Each inorganic unit is surrounded by eight carboxylate groups arising from the ligands. While MOFs built up from 12-connected Zr6 oxoclusters are the most common, many recent studies have described new solids built up from carboxylate deficient Zr6 nodes (either 10, 8, or 6 connected). In the case of the 8-fold connection, the carboxylates are usually organized to define a cubic geometry (point group symmetry D 4h ). In the present solid, they define a rare triangular gyro-biprism or gyrobifastigium (obtained by fusing together two triangular prisms through a square face after a 90° rotation) with an ideal D 2d  symmetry (see Figure S7). The ligands assemble into dimers with their rings roughly parallel to each other, with one carboxylate group in the plane of the aromatic ring and one outside (see b and S8). These dimers connect two oxoclusters together, leading on the whole to a distorted diamond (dia) type network (c). Regarding the protonation state of the inorganic μ3 ligands (O2-/OH-), the structure solution indicates the presence of terminal DMF molecules and hence likely charge balancing oxo bridges giving rise to the formula Zr6O8(STz)4(DMF)8. Nevertheless, the final protonation state might depend on the activation procedure, and its unambiguous determination in carboxylate deficient Zr6 units is still an issue and a matter of debate. Indeed, as proposed by Zhou et al. for PCN-222, a washing step with an aqueous HCl solution prior to activation seems to qualitatively improve the crystallinity of MIL-161, together with a positive impact on the reversibility of the flexible behavior (see Figure S10). While the mechanism is not clear, it might be associated with acid-base reactions involving bridging and/or terminal ligands.

elements.content: Crystal structure of MIL-161 (here DMF@MIL-161). ZrO8 polyhedra are shown in blue: (a) the Zr6O8(CO2)8 inorganic unit (carboxylate groups and DMF molecules are shown in yellow and gray respectively); (b) pair of ligands (carbon, white; sulfur, yellow; nitrogen, blue); (c) the whole structure (ligands either in red or in yellow).
elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal structure of MIL-161 (here DMF@MIL-161). ZrO8 polyhedra are shown in blue: (a) the Zr6O8(CO2)8 inorganic unit (carboxylate groups and DMF molecules are shown in yellow and gray respectively); (b) pair of ligands (carbon, white; sulfur, yellow; nitrogen, blue); (c) the whole structure (ligands either in red or in yellow).

elements.content: One of the striking features of some MOFs is their structural flexibility, i.e., the adaptation of the pore size and shape to their content, while the solid remains crystalline. Adsorption of guests can in this case be directly (and unambiguously) observed by diffraction techniques, as the unit-cell parameters could be characteristic of the pore content. As mentioned earlier, desolvation of MIL-161 is accompanied by a broadening of Bragg peaks on the XRPD pattern. This phenomenon is reversible, as the redispersion of the dry solid in solvents leads to the recovery of the crystalline state (see Figure S11), suggesting a flexible behavior. The dried state adsorbs a very minor adsorption of N2 at 77 K, and hence does not present any permanent porosity. As the broadening of the Bragg peaks is not associated with a significant shift, such a result probably arises from local distortions of the intrinsically flexible ligands leading to too small pore windows rather that to pore closure, as commonly found in flexible MOFs built up from rigid ligands (such as the MIL-53­(Fe) and MIL-88 series). In contrast, adsorption in the liquid phase is feasible, as confirmed by the examination of the XRPD patterns of MIL-161 suspended in various solvents (). In all cases (ethanol, DMF, and water), the solids remain highly crystalline. This first confirms the robustness of MIL-161, especially in aqueous medium, as the XRPD diagram remains unaltered after weeks. Moreover, the position of the Bragg peaks strongly depends on the solvent. These shifts are associated with noticeable changes of the unit-cell parameters (see ), with variation of a, c, and V up to 8, 29, and 15% respectively, hence confirming the adsorption of the solvent. Here, the structural flexibility arises from the thioalkyl links in the ligand. Indeed, when comparing the structure of MIL-161 in water and DMF, while the N–C–S–CH2 dihedral angles remain rather unchanged (variation <1°), the variation of the C–S–CH2–CO2 angles is more pronounced (∼6 and 11°, see Figure S8 for details).
elements.clean_text: One of the striking features of some MOFs is their structural flexibility, i.e., the adaptation of the pore size and shape to their content, while the solid remains crystalline. Adsorption of guests can in this case be directly (and unambiguously) observed by diffraction techniques, as the unit-cell parameters could be characteristic of the pore content. As mentioned earlier, desolvation of MIL-161 is accompanied by a broadening of Bragg peaks on the XRPD pattern. This phenomenon is reversible, as the redispersion of the dry solid in  solvents leads to the recovery of the crystalline state (see Figure S11), suggesting a flexible behavior. The dried state adsorbs a very minor adsorption of N2 at 77 K, and hence does not present any permanent porosity. As the broadening of the Bragg peaks is not associated with a significant shift, such a result probably arises from local distortions of the intrinsically flexible ligands leading to too small pore windows rather that to pore closure, as commonly found in flexible MOFs built up from rigid ligands (such as the MIL-53(Fe) and MIL-88 series). In contrast, adsorption in the liquid phase is feasible, as confirmed by the examination of the XRPD patterns of MIL-161 suspended in various solvents (). In all cases (ethanol, DMF, and water), the solids remain highly crystalline. This first confirms the robustness of MIL-161, especially in aqueous medium, as the XRPD diagram remains unaltered after weeks. Moreover, the position of the Bragg peaks strongly depends on the solvent. These shifts are associated with noticeable changes of the unit-cell parameters (see ), with variation of a, c, and V up to 8, 29, and 15% respectively, hence confirming the adsorption of the solvent. Here, the structural flexibility arises from the thioalkyl links in the ligand. Indeed, when comparing the structure of MIL-161 in water and DMF, while the N-C-S-CH2 dihedral angles remain rather unchanged (variation <1°), the variation of the C-S-CH2-CO2 angles is more pronounced (~6 and 11°, see Figure S8 for details).

elements.content: XRPD patterns of MIL-161 when dispersed in various solvents. The evolution of the 200, 101, 220, and 211 Bragg peaks is highlighted (λ = 1.5406 Å).
elements.clean_text: 2  XRPD patterns of MIL-161 when dispersed in various solvents. The evolution of the 200, 101, 220, and 211 Bragg peaks is highlighted (λ = 1.5406 Å).

elements.content: The optical properties of MIL-161 were evaluated in suspension in solvents (either water or ethanol, see below), and compared with the one of the free H2STz ligand in solution, while keeping the concentration of the s-tetrazine core constant. As expected, both H2STz and MIL-161 are luminescent, with an emission band centered at 580 nm (excitation at either 409 or 525 nm) in both cases (Figure S17), but with a faster decay for the solid, with an average lifetime of 0.95 and 0.44 ns in ethanol for H2STz and MIL-161 respectively (see Figure S15 and Table S2).
elements.clean_text:
Photophysical Properties

The optical properties of MIL-161 were evaluated in suspension in solvents (either water or ethanol, see below), and compared with the one of the free H2STz ligand in solution, while keeping the concentration of the s-tetrazine core constant. As expected, both H2STz and MIL-161 are luminescent, with an emission band centered at 580 nm (excitation at either 409 or 525 nm) in both cases (Figure S17), but with a faster decay for the solid, with an average lifetime of 0.95 and 0.44 ns in ethanol for H2STz and MIL-161 respectively (see Figure S15 and Table S2).

elements.content: The quenching ability of various electron-rich molecules dissolved in either ethanol or water was further evaluated. In a first step, two aromatic amines, namely, N,N-dimethylaniline (DMA) and triphenylamine (TPA), were considered. Both H2STz and MIL-161 were exposed to increasing amount of both electron-rich molecules. As expected, both DMA and TPA induce a quenching of the intensity of luminescence I of free H2STz (see Figures S19 and S21). The luminescence decays can be fitted with the Stern–Volmer equation, I 0 / I − 1 = K S V [ q u e n c h e r ] where I 0 is the initial fluorescence intensity, and K SV is the Stern–Volmer constant (see and Supporting Information for details), that quantifies the sensitivity toward a given quencher. This equation is indeed suitable for intermolecular quenching reactions and properly models the behavior of s-tetrazines in solution, the value of K SV being slightly higher for DMA than TPA (see Table S3).
elements.clean_text: The quenching ability of various electron-rich molecules dissolved in either ethanol or water was further evaluated. In a first step, two aromatic amines, namely, N,N-dimethylaniline (DMA) and triphenylamine (TPA), were considered. Both H2STz and MIL-161 were exposed to increasing amount of both electron-rich molecules. As expected, both DMA and TPA induce a quenching of the intensity of luminescence I of free H2STz (see Figures S19 and S21). The luminescence decays can be fitted with the Stern-Volmer equation,      I   0   / I - 1 =   K   S V    [ q u e n c h e r ]    where I 0 is the initial fluorescence intensity, and K SV is the Stern-Volmer constant (see  and Supporting Information for details), that quantifies the sensitivity toward a given quencher. This equation is indeed suitable for intermolecular quenching reactions and properly models the behavior of s-tetrazines in solution, the value of K SV being slightly higher for DMA than TPA (see Table S3).

elements.content: Stern–Volmer plots of a suspension of MIL-161 (black) and free H2STz (red) as a function of the concentration of either DMA (top) or TPA (bottom).
elements.clean_text: 3  Stern-Volmer plots of a suspension of MIL-161 (black) and free H2STz (red) as a function of the concentration of either DMA (top) or TPA (bottom).

elements.content: The behavior of MIL-161 strongly differs. While, for the smaller amine (DMA, see Figure S18), a clear quenching is observed, the effect of the bulkier TPA is far less marked (Figure S20). In the first case, the variation of I 0/I with the concentration of quencher remains linear (, top), with a K SV value of the same order of magnitude as H2STz (see Table S3). On the contrary, for TPA, only a slight decrease followed by a plateau is observed (, bottom), which prevents the calculation of K SV.
elements.clean_text: The behavior of MIL-161 strongly differs. While, for the smaller amine (DMA, see Figure S18), a clear quenching is observed, the effect of the bulkier TPA is far less marked (Figure S20). In the first case, the variation of I 0/I with the concentration of quencher remains linear (, top), with a K SV value of the same order of magnitude as H2STz (see Table S3). On the contrary, for TPA, only a slight decrease followed by a plateau is observed (, bottom), which prevents the calculation of K SV.

elements.content: This suggests that, in the case of MIL-161, the quenching of the fluorescence arises not only from electronic factors (as found in solution), but also from steric effects: the smaller DMA molecules are likely to enter the pores, while the bulkier TPA cannot, hence leading to a limited quenching ability related to its interaction only at the outer surface of the MOF particles. In order to support such a mechanism, we took advantage of the flexible behavior of MIL-161. XRPD patterns of the title solid suspended in ethanol, without any quencher, and in the presence of either TPA or DMA were collected (see ). Whereas, in the presence of TPA, the XRPD pattern remains almost unchanged, the one in the presence of DMA is different. This was confirmed by the change of the unit-cell parameters (see ), which indicated a shrinkage of the structure in the presence of DMA. This unambiguously proves that DMA is adsorbed in the pores, hence leading to a pore opening distinct from the one in pure ethanol. This means that the quenching of the fluorescence is here truly associated with adsorption of DMA within the pores. This experiment still does not entirely rule out any adsorption of TPA within the pores, although this seems unlikely considering the pore size together with the shape of the quenching curve (which is in favor of a TPA–STz interaction at the surface of the crystallites, as only a small fraction of STz (<15%) is active).
elements.clean_text: This suggests that, in the case of MIL-161, the quenching of the fluorescence arises not only from electronic factors (as found in solution), but also from steric effects: the smaller DMA molecules are likely to enter the pores, while the bulkier TPA cannot, hence leading to a limited quenching ability related to its interaction only at the outer surface of the MOF particles. In order to support such a mechanism, we took advantage of the flexible behavior of MIL-161. XRPD patterns of the title solid suspended in ethanol, without any quencher, and in the presence of either TPA or DMA were collected (see ). Whereas, in the presence of TPA, the XRPD pattern remains almost unchanged, the one in the presence of DMA is different. This was confirmed by the change of the unit-cell parameters (see ), which indicated a shrinkage of the structure in the presence of DMA. This unambiguously proves that DMA is adsorbed in the pores, hence leading to a pore opening distinct from the one in pure ethanol. This means that the quenching of the fluorescence is here truly associated with adsorption of DMA within the pores. This experiment still does not entirely rule out any adsorption of TPA within the pores, although this seems unlikely considering the pore size together with the shape of the quenching curve (which is in favor of a TPA-STz interaction at the surface of the crystallites, as only a small fraction of STz (<15%) is active).

elements.content: XRPD patterns of MIL-161 dispersed in pure ethanol (bottom), a 20 mM solution of TPA in ethanol (middle), and a 100 mM solution of DMA in ethanol (top) (λ = 1.5406 Å).
elements.clean_text: 4  XRPD patterns of MIL-161 dispersed in pure ethanol (bottom), a 20 mM solution of TPA in ethanol (middle), and a 100 mM solution of DMA in ethanol (top) (λ = 1.5406 Å).

elements.content: Phenol is another class of electron-rich chemicals which deserves to be detected. Its quenching ability toward MIL-161 and free H2STz was evaluated both in ethanol and in water. The corresponding Stern–Volmer plots are shown (see Figures S22–S25 and S28 for the corresponding fluorescence spectra and XRPD patterns respectively). In all cases, the exposure to phenol leads to a quenching of the fluorescence of the tetrazine core. Nevertheless, in ethanol, the efficiency is rather poor, for both the solid and the free ligand (see Table S3), while significantly higher in water. More interestingly, in this solvent, the quenching is more pronounced for MIL-161 than for H2STz, with a sensitivity three times higher (see and Table S3).
elements.clean_text: Phenol is another class of electron-rich chemicals which deserves to be detected. Its quenching ability toward MIL-161 and free H2STz was evaluated both in ethanol and in water. The corresponding Stern-Volmer plots are shown  (see Figures S22-S25 and S28 for the corresponding fluorescence spectra and XRPD patterns respectively). In all cases, the exposure to phenol leads to a quenching of the fluorescence of the tetrazine core. Nevertheless, in ethanol, the efficiency is rather poor, for both the solid and the free ligand (see Table S3), while significantly higher in water. More interestingly, in this solvent, the quenching is more pronounced for MIL-161 than for H2STz, with a sensitivity three times higher (see  and Table S3).

elements.content: Stern–Volmer plots of a suspension of MIL-161 (blue or green) and free H2STz (red or black) as a function of the concentration of phenol both in ethanol and in water (respectively).
elements.clean_text: 5  Stern-Volmer plots of a suspension of MIL-161 (blue or green) and free H2STz (red or black) as a function of the concentration of phenol both in ethanol and in water (respectively).

elements.content: As mentioned above, the quenching of the fluorescence requests here an interaction between the tetrazine core and the electron-rich molecules. In water, both organic species (H2STz and phenol) are prone to interact together, whereas ethanol solvates more easily these organic species and prevents their close contact. Related features should happen for MIL-161. As shown above, the optical detection relies in this case on the adsorption of the quencher within the pores. As already highlighted, e.g., in the case of the encapsulation of drugs within MOFs, the adsorption of molecules from solution results from the competition between various intermolecular interactions, namely, MOF–solvent, MOF–guest, and guest–solvent. Because of its organic constituent, MIL-161 is expected to interact more strongly with polar organic species such as phenol and ethanol than with water. MOF–solvent and phenol–solvent interactions are thus expected to be lower in water than in ethanol, hence favoring the adsorption of phenol and thus the quenching of the fluorescence in water.
elements.clean_text: As mentioned above, the quenching of the fluorescence requests here an interaction between the tetrazine core and the electron-rich molecules. In water, both organic species (H2STz and phenol) are prone to interact together, whereas ethanol solvates more easily these organic species and prevents their close contact. Related features should happen for MIL-161. As shown above, the optical detection relies in this case on the adsorption of the quencher within the pores. As already highlighted, e.g., in the case of the encapsulation of drugs within MOFs, the adsorption of molecules from solution results from the competition between various intermolecular interactions, namely, MOF-solvent, MOF-guest, and guest-solvent. Because of its organic constituent, MIL-161 is expected to interact more strongly with polar organic species such as phenol and ethanol than with water. MOF-solvent and phenol-solvent interactions are thus expected to be lower in water than in ethanol, hence favoring the adsorption of phenol and thus the quenching of the fluorescence in water.

elements.content: We reported here a new porous MOF built up from an s-tetrazine dicarboxylate derivative and Zr­(IV), which was found to be flexible as well as stable in aqueous medium. Because of the nature of the organic ligand, this solid is able to detect electron-rich molecules thanks to the quenching of its fluorescence, such phenomenon being associated with adsorption, as unambiguously proven by X-ray diffraction analyses. As evidenced with aromatic amines, such adsorption-driven detection is size-selective thanks to the molecular sieving effect associated with the microporosity. It is noteworthy that, thanks to the amphiphilic character of the MOF, the sensibility to phenol was moreover found to be significantly higher in water than in ethanol, likely because of its higher adsorption in the aqueous medium resulting from a more favorable MOF–solvent, MOF–phenol, and phenol–solvent set of interactions. Hence, when compared to s-tetrazine derivatives dissolved in solution, the two specific features associated with the use of solid porous fluorophores (steric constraints and polarity of the walls) allow the achievement of good sorption selectivities leading to an enhanced detection selectivity. Although the fluorescence of the title solid is too low for any practical use, this study suggests that fluorescent MOFs built up from more emissive tetrazine derivatives might be interesting for the development of new solid state sensors for electron-rich molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We reported here a new porous MOF built up from an s-tetrazine dicarboxylate derivative and Zr(IV), which was found to be flexible as well as stable in aqueous medium. Because of the nature of the organic ligand, this solid is able to detect electron-rich molecules thanks to the quenching of its fluorescence, such phenomenon being associated with adsorption, as unambiguously proven by X-ray diffraction analyses. As evidenced with aromatic amines, such adsorption-driven detection is size-selective thanks to the molecular sieving effect associated with the microporosity. It is noteworthy that, thanks to the amphiphilic character of the MOF, the sensibility to phenol was moreover found to be significantly higher in water than in ethanol, likely because of its higher adsorption in the aqueous medium resulting from a more favorable MOF-solvent, MOF-phenol, and phenol-solvent set of interactions. Hence, when compared to s-tetrazine derivatives dissolved in solution, the two specific features associated with the use of solid porous fluorophores (steric constraints and polarity of the walls) allow the achievement of good sorption selectivities leading to an enhanced detection selectivity. Although the fluorescence of the title solid is too low for any practical use, this study suggests that fluorescent MOFs built up from more emissive tetrazine derivatives might be interesting for the development of new solid state sensors for electron-rich molecules.

cln_elements.content: As expected for such a s-tetrazine derivative, the UV–visible absorption spectrum presents two absorption bands, centered at 409 and 525 nm (ε = 818 and 481 L mol–1 cm–1 respectively) and associated with π–π* and n−π* electronic transitions, respectively. After excitation at either 409 or 525 nm, an emission peak centered at 580 nm is observed with a modest quantum yield (0.4(2) %), again in agreement with previous studies of thiol functionalized s-tetrazines (Figure S16).
cln_elements.clean_text: As expected for such a s-tetrazine derivative, the UV-visible absorption spectrum presents two absorption bands, centered at 409 and 525 nm (ε = 818 and 481 L mol-1 cm-1 respectively) and associated with π-π* and n-π* electronic transitions, respectively. After excitation at either 409 or 525 nm, an emission peak centered at 580 nm is observed with a modest quantum yield (0.4(2) %), again in agreement with previous studies of thiol functionalized s-tetrazines (Figure S16).

peak_spectrum.condition: associated with π-π* and n-π* electronic transitions

cln_elements.content: Crystal structure of MIL-161 (here DMF@MIL-161). ZrO8 polyhedra are shown in blue: (a) the Zr6O8(CO2)8 inorganic unit (carboxylate groups and DMF molecules are shown in yellow and gray respectively); (b) pair of ligands (carbon, white; sulfur, yellow; nitrogen, blue); (c) the whole structure (ligands either in red or in yellow).

metadata.title:
A Flexible Fluorescent Zr Carboxylate Metal–Organic
Framework for the Detection of Electron-Rich Molecules in Solution
